results.title: Alive via satellite
results.brief_description: By international agreement, the Federal Seasafety Centre in Canberra is responsible for search and rescue over an area covering one-ninth of the earth’s oceans. It’s an enormous undertaking - keeping watch for those in peril on the sea over 20 million square kilometres of ocean and 37000 kilometres of coastline. Now space age technology is lending a helping hand. The Cospas/Sarsat International Search and Rescue System uses four space satellites to keep a constant and precise lookout for emergency position indicating radio beacons (EPIRB) and this video explains how this system works.

results.title: Alimentary tract
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: Intended as a supplement to Digestion of foods, this film treats in detail, motility phenomena of the gastro-intestinal tract. Actual photography reveals different types of movements in the stomach, such as hypermotility, inhibition, antiperistalsis, hunger contractions and normal movements.

results.title: Alice Moyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Alice Moyle was born in South Africa on 25th December 1908 and spent her first four years there before migrating out to Australia with her parents. She learned the piano and studied music at school, attending the University of Melbourne Conservatorium where she graduated with a Bachelor of Music in 1930. Alice Moyle’s first experience of Aboriginal music was listening to recordings made by Professor Elkin when she was attending courses at the Faculty of Music at Sydney University. These recordings were to prepare teachers for work in the outback. In 1959 Alice made the first of many field trips into the outback to continue the process of recording and archiving Aboriginal music. She has continually tried to inspire others with her experiences and knowledge in Aboriginal music and culture and is adamant that music be included as an essential component in the study of Aboriginal culture. This documentary is a recorded interview between Alice Moyle and James Murdoch.

results.title: Ali and his baby camel
results.brief_description: The relationship between a little boy in the Middle East and his pet camel. Designed to introduce small children to the idea of caring properly for pets, to show the camel as both a pet and essential part of the desert community, and to show animals and humans adapt to their environment.

results.title: Alexeieff's commercials
results.brief_description: A collection of advertising films made by French lithographer and animator, Alexander Alexeieff, some using his own ‘pinboard’ device, and others more conventional methods of animation. The reel includes: Fumees - which took a year to make on the pinboard and lasts barely a minute, with the smoke made from hundreds of fine oscillating lines superimposed densely on each frame, and Le seve de la terre - with delicately animated glass beads to represent drops of oil.

results.title: Alexander Turnbull's library
results.creator_credit: Paul Maunder, Ronald Bowie and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: The film takes the viewer through an ordinary day of the famous Alexander Turnbull Library showing glimpses of the treasures - rare books, New Zealand and Pacific collection, manuscripts and paintings. The viewer learns that the historic building is no longer safe, and is about to be destroyed for the construction of a motorway.

results.title: Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic Age
results.brief_description: Alexander’s campaigns and the spread of Greek culture are the focuses of this film. The flowering of commerce, art and science that was the Hellenistic Age is reflected in the views of Rhodes and Delas, Hellenistic sculpture, the Temple of Zeus and the archaeological treasures of Sidon Sarcophagus, the Issis mosaic and the ruins of Persepolis.

results.title: Alexander Nevsky [study extract]
results.brief_description: One of a series of short extracts from feature films intended for study of cinema technique. During the 13th century, Russia was endangered by the invasion of Teutonic Knights, the founders of Prussia. Under the leadership of Prince Alexander Nevsky, the Russians unite and counter the German onslaught on the ice of Lake Peipus and defeat them. The commencement of the battle is the subject of the excerpt. At first Nevsky and his aides are seen on a high rock - the camera intercutting faces on the waiting soldiers and the preparation of the enemy camp. The Germans begin to advance, gathering speed. Battle is joined.

results.title: Alexander and the terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day (K)
results.brief_description: Anyone can have a bad day, but no one wants to have one quite as awful as seven year old Alexander’s. Whether it’s his mother forgetting to pack dessert in his lunch, or the dentist discovering he has a new cavity, nothing goes right for Alexander from sun-up to sun-down. Alexander will not only win children’s sympathy, he’ll remind the child in every adult how those little tragedies can accumulate to make an otherwise normal day seem like a catastrophe. Based on the best selling children’s book by Judith Viorst.

results.title: Alexander and the car with a missing headlight
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag, Peter Fleischmann, Institut für Film und Bild and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Released by the Weston Woods Studios in 1966 and English language version directed by Cynthia Freitag. A fantasy about a small boy’s adventures as he drives around the world in an old car. Pictures, sound effects and narrative comments are by children of different nations. From the book by Peter Fleischmann and Morton Schindel. Suitable for lower primary level.
